name: Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)
summary: Vitamin B1, or thiamine, is an essential water-soluble vitamin required for energy metabolism, nervous system function, and cognitive health.
description: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) is a vital coenzyme in carbohydrate metabolism, helping convert glucose into energy. It is essential for the functioning of the nervous system, muscles, and heart. Deficiency can lead to serious neurological and cardiovascular disorders, including beriberi and Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome, particularly in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Supplementation supports energy production, nerve health, and may be used in psychiatry for alcohol-related conditions and stress-related fatigue.

metadata.natural_source: Whole grains, pork, legumes, nuts, seeds
metadata.prescription_status: Over-the-counter supplement; prescription formulations available for medical use
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement and approved drug (in injectable form)

primary_indications: Prevention and treatment of thiamine deficiency
monitoring_required: Electrolyte balance when correcting deficiency (risk of refeeding syndrome)

items: Prevention and treatment of thiamine deficiency
Management of Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome in alcohol dependence
Support for energy metabolism and nervous system health

sections.text: Thiamine functions as a coenzyme (thiamine pyrophosphate, TPP) in carbohydrate metabolism and the Krebs cycle, essential for ATP production. It also plays a role in neurotransmitter synthesis and nerve conduction.

adult.typical: Oral: 50–300 mg/day for supplementation or deficiency prevention
adult.clinical: IV or IM: 100 mg to 500 mg daily for treatment of Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome or severe deficiency

sections.pediatric: 1–2 mg/day for supplementation; higher under clinical supervision for deficiency treatment

sections.text: Neurological improvements in deficiency states may be seen within days; full recovery may take weeks depending on severity.

other: High doses are generally well tolerated but unnecessary in the absence of deficiency.
Caution with rapid IV administration due to rare risk of anaphylaxis.

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended doses; higher doses may be prescribed for deficiency
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk but safe at nutritional levels
sections.pediatrics: Safe at recommended dietary allowance; higher doses for deficiency under supervision
sections.geriatrics: Safe and often beneficial; deficiency more common in older adults

sections.text: No tapering required; can discontinue abruptly without withdrawal effects.

items: Essential for carbohydrate metabolism; deficiency risk increases with high carbohydrate intake without supplementation.
Thiamine deficiency is common in chronic alcohol use disorder and malnutrition.
Prompt treatment can prevent irreversible neurological damage in Wernicke’s encephalopathy.
